Separating cycles and isoperimetric
inequalities in the uniform infinite
planar quadrangulation

Jean-François Le Galllabel=e1]jean-francois.legall@math.u-psud.fr [    Thomas Lehéricylabel=e2]thomas.lehericy@math.u-psud.fr [ Université Paris-Sud Institut de Mathématique d’Orsay, Université Paris-Sud, 91405 Orsay, France
Abstract

We study geometric properties of the infinite random lattice called the uniform infinite planar quadrangulation or UIPQ. We establish a precise form of a conjecture of Krikun stating that the minimal size of a cycle that separates the ball of radius R𝑅R centered at the root vertex from infinity grows linearly in R𝑅R. As a consequence, we derive certain isoperimetric bounds showing that the boundary size of any simply connected set A𝐴A consisting of a finite union of faces of the UIPQ and containing the root vertex is bounded below by a (random) constant times |A|1/4​(log⁡|A|)−(3/4)−δsuperscript𝐴14superscript𝐴34𝛿|A|^{1/4}(\log|A|)^{-(3/4)-\delta}, where the volume |A|𝐴|A| is the number of faces in A𝐴A.

1 Introduction

In the recent years, much work has been devoted to discrete and continuous models of random geometry in two dimensions. Two of the most popular discrete models are the uniform infinite planar triangulation (or UIPT), which was introduced by Angel and Schramm [1, 2] and in fact motivated much of the subsequent work, and the uniform infinite planar quadrangulation (or UIPQ). In the present work, we concentrate on the UIPQ, although we believe that our methods can be adapted to give similar results for the UIPT. Roughly speaking, the UIPQ is a random infinite graph embedded in the plane, such that all faces (connected components of the complement of edges) are quadrangles, possibly with two edges glued together. See Fig.4 below for an illustration of what the UIPQ may look like near its root vertex. We study certain geometric properties of the UIPQ, concerning the existence of “small” cycles that separate a large ball centered at the root vertex from infinity, with applications to isoperimetric inequalities.

The starting point of our work is a conjecture of Krikun in the paper [14] which provided the first construction of the UIPQ as the local limit of uniform planar quadrangulations with a fixed number of faces (another construction was suggested by Chassaing and Durhuus [3], and the equivalence between the two approaches was established by Ménard [18] — see also [9] for a third construction). Denote the UIPQ by 𝒫𝒫{\mathcal{P}}, and, for every integer r≥1𝑟1r\geq 1, let Br​(𝒫)subscript𝐵𝑟𝒫B_{r}({\mathcal{P}}) stand for the ball of radius r𝑟r centered at the root vertex, which is defined as the union of all faces that are incident to at least one vertex whose graph distance from the root is at most r−1𝑟1r-1. The complement of the ball Br​(𝒫)subscript𝐵𝑟𝒫B_{r}({\mathcal{P}}) is in general not connected, but there is a unique unbounded component, whose boundary is called the exterior boundary of the ball. The set inside the exterior boundary, which may be obtained by filling in the “bounded holes” of the ball, is called the (standard) hull of radius r𝑟r and will be denoted by Br∙​(𝒫)subscriptsuperscript𝐵∙𝑟𝒫B^{\bullet}_{r}({\mathcal{P}}). It is known that the size of the exterior boundary, that is, the number of edges in this boundary, grows like r2superscript𝑟2r^{2} when r→∞→𝑟r\to\infty: See [7] for more precise asymptotics obtained both for the UIPT and the UIPQ. On the other hand, Krikun constructed a cycle that separates the ball Br​(𝒫)subscript𝐵𝑟𝒫B_{r}({\mathcal{P}}) from infinity and whose size grows linearly in r𝑟r when r𝑟r is large. Here we say that a cycle 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} made of edges of the UIPQ separates a finite set A𝐴A of vertices from infinity if A𝐴A does not intersect 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} but any path from a vertex of A𝐴A to infinity intersects 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} (see Fig. 1 for a schematic illustration). Krikun conjectured that the cycle he constructed is essentially the shortest possible, meaning that the minimal size of a cycle that separates the ball Br​(𝒫)subscript𝐵𝑟𝒫B_{r}({\mathcal{P}}) from infinity must be linear in r𝑟r. A weak form of this conjecture was derived in [5], but the results of this paper did not exclude the possibility that a ball could be separated from infinity by a small cycle lying “very far away” from the ball.

The following theorem provides quantitative estimates that confirm Krikun’s conjecture.

Theorem 1.

For every integer R≥1𝑅1R\geq 1, let L​(R)𝐿𝑅L(R) be the smallest length of a cycle separating BR​(𝒫)subscript𝐵𝑅𝒫B_{R}({\mathcal{P}}) from infinity.

  • (i)

    For every δ<2𝛿2\delta<2, there exists a constant Cδsubscript𝐶𝛿C_{\delta} such that, for every R≥1𝑅1R\geq 1, for every ε∈(0,1)𝜀01\varepsilon\in(0,1),

    ℙ​(L​(R)≤ε​R)≤Cδ​εδ.ℙ𝐿𝑅𝜀𝑅subscript𝐶𝛿superscript𝜀𝛿{\mathbb{P}}(L(R)\leq\varepsilon R)\leq C_{\delta}\,\varepsilon^{\delta}.
  • (ii)

    There exist constants C𝐶C and λ>0𝜆0\lambda>0 such that, for every a>0𝑎0a>0 and R≥1𝑅1R\geq 1,

    ℙ​(L​(R)≥a​R)≤C​e−λ​a.ℙ𝐿𝑅𝑎𝑅𝐶superscript𝑒𝜆𝑎{\mathbb{P}}(L(R)\geq aR)\leq C\,e^{-\lambda a}.

Part (ii) of the theorem is proved by using the separating cycle introduced by Krikun and sharpening the estimates in [14]. So the most interesting part of the theorem is part (i). We believe that our condition δ<2𝛿2\delta<2 is close to optimal, in the sense that, for R𝑅R large, ℙ​(L​(R)≤ε​R)ℙ𝐿𝑅𝜀𝑅{\mathbb{P}}(L(R)\leq\varepsilon R) should behave like ε2superscript𝜀2\varepsilon^{2}, possibly up to logarithmic corrections. At the end of Section 4, we provide a short argument showing that the probability ℙ​(L​(R)≤ε​R)ℙ𝐿𝑅𝜀𝑅{\mathbb{P}}(L(R)\leq\varepsilon R) is bounded below by Const.​ε3Const.superscript𝜀3\hbox{Const.}\,\varepsilon^{3} when R𝑅R is large.

The proof of part (i) relies on a technical estimate which is of independent interest and that we now present. We first label vertices of the UIPQ by their distances from the root vertex, and for every integer r≥1𝑟1r\geq 1, we say that a face of the UIPQ is r𝑟r-simple if the labels of the vertices incident to this face take the three values r−1,r,r+1𝑟1𝑟𝑟1r-1,r,r+1 (note that there are faces such that labels of incident vertices take only two values, these faces are called confluent in [4]). In each r𝑟r-simple face, we draw a “diagonal” connecting the two corners labeled r𝑟r (these two corners may correspond to the same vertex), and such diagonals, which are not edges of the UIPQ, are called r𝑟r-diagonals. Then, there is a “maximal” cycle made of r𝑟r-diagonals, which is simple and such that the labels of vertices lying in the unbounded component of the complement of this cycle are at least r+1𝑟1r+1. We denote this maximal cycle by 𝒞rsubscript𝒞𝑟\mathcal{C}_{r}, and, for 1≤r<r′1𝑟superscript𝑟′1\leq r<r^{\prime}, we define the annulus 𝒞​(r,r′)𝒞𝑟superscript𝑟′\mathcal{C}(r,r^{\prime}) as the part of the UIPQ between the cycles 𝒞rsubscript𝒞𝑟\mathcal{C}_{r} and 𝒞r′subscript𝒞superscript𝑟′\mathcal{C}_{r^{\prime}}. See Section 2 below for more precise definitions. Note that the cycles 𝒞rsubscript𝒞𝑟\mathcal{C}_{r} are not made of edges of the UIPQ in contrast with the separating cycles that we consider in Theorem 1 and in the next proposition.

Proposition 2.

Let β∈(0,3)𝛽03\beta\in(0,3). There exists a constant Cβ′subscriptsuperscript𝐶′𝛽C^{\prime}_{\beta} such that, for every integer r≥1𝑟1r\geq 1 and for every integer n≥1𝑛1n\geq 1, the probability that there exists a cycle of the UIPQ of length smaller than r𝑟r, which is contained in 𝒞​(n​r,(n+2)​r)𝒞𝑛𝑟𝑛2𝑟\mathcal{C}(nr,(n+2)r), does not intersect 𝒞(n+2)​rsubscript𝒞𝑛2𝑟\mathcal{C}_{(n+2)r}, and disconnects the root vertex from infinity, is bounded above by Cβ′​n−βsubscriptsuperscript𝐶′𝛽superscript𝑛𝛽C^{\prime}_{\beta}\,n^{-\beta}.

The condition that the cycle does not intersect 𝒞(n+2)​rsubscript𝒞𝑛2𝑟\mathcal{C}_{(n+2)r} is included for technical convenience, and could be removed from the statement.

The proof of Proposition 2 relies on a “skeleton decomposition” of the UIPQ, which is already presented in the work of Krikun [14]. Our presentation is however different from the one in [14] and better suited to our purposes. We introduce and use the notion of a truncated quadrangulation, which is basically a planar map with a boundary, where all faces (distinct from the distinguished one) are quadrangles, except for those incident to the boundary, which are triangles (see Section 2.1 for precise definitions). The annulus 𝒞​(r,r′)𝒞𝑟superscript𝑟′\mathcal{C}(r,r^{\prime}) can be viewed as a truncated quadrangulation of the cylinder of height r′−rsuperscript𝑟′𝑟r^{\prime}-r. Our motivation for introducing truncated quadrangulations comes from the fact that they allow certain explicit calculations in the UIPQ. For every integer r≥1𝑟1r\geq 1, we define the “truncated hull” of radius r𝑟r of the UIPQ, which is basically the part of the UIPQ inside the maximal cycle 𝒞rsubscript𝒞𝑟\mathcal{C}_{r} (see Section 2.2 for a precise definition). This truncated hull is different from the standard hull Br∙​(𝒫)subscriptsuperscript𝐵∙𝑟𝒫B^{\bullet}_{r}({\mathcal{P}}) introduced above, which had been considered in [6, 7] in particular, but it is essentially the same object as the hull defined in [14]. It turns out that it is possible to compute the law of the truncated hull in a rather explicit manner (Corollary 8) and in particular the law of the perimeter of the hull has a very simple form (Proposition 11). These calculations make heavy use of the skeleton decomposition of the UIPQ, and more generally of the similar decomposition for truncated quadrangulations of the cylinder. This decomposition involves a forest structure, which was already described by Krikun [14, Section 3.2] and is similar to the one for triangulations that was discovered in [13] and heavily used in the recent work [8] dealing with first-passage percolation on the UIPT.

Given the forest structure associated with a truncated quadrangulation of the cylinder, the idea of the proof of Proposition 2 is as follows. One first observes that, with high probability, there exist, for some δ>0𝛿0\delta>0, more than nδsuperscript𝑛𝛿n^{\delta} trees with maximal height in the forest coding the annulus 𝒞​(n​r,(n+2)​r)𝒞𝑛𝑟𝑛2𝑟\mathcal{C}(nr,(n+2)r). For each of these trees, one can find a vertex on the cycle 𝒞n​rsubscript𝒞𝑛𝑟\mathcal{C}_{nr} (the interior boundary of the annulus) which is connected to the exterior boundary 𝒞(n+2)​rsubscript𝒞𝑛2𝑟\mathcal{C}_{(n+2)r} by a path of length 2​r2𝑟2r. Assuming that there is a cycle of length r𝑟r in the annulus that disconnects the root vertex from infinity, it follows that any two of these particular vertices of 𝒞n​rsubscript𝒞𝑛𝑟\mathcal{C}_{nr} can be connected by a path staying in the annulus with length at most 5​r5𝑟5r. Results of Curien and Miermont [10] about the graph distances between boundary points in infinite quadrangulations with a boundary, show that this cannot occur except on a set of small probability.

Our lower bounds on the minimal size of separating cycles lead to interesting isoperimetric inequalities showing informally that the size of the boundary of a simply connected set which is a finite union of faces and contains the root vertex must be at least of the order of the volume raised to the power 1/4141/4. The fact that we cannot do better than the power 1/4141/4 follows from part (ii) in Theorem 1, since it is well known [3, 6, 7] that the volume of the ball, or of the standard hull, of radius r𝑟r is of order r4superscript𝑟4r^{4}. We refer to [17, Chapter 6] for a thorough discussion of isoperimetric inequalities on infinite graphs.

Let 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K} denote the collection of all simply connected compact subsets of the plane that are finite unions of faces of the UIPQ (including their boundaries) and contain the root vertex. For A∈𝒦𝐴𝒦A\in\mathcal{K}, the volume of A𝐴A, denoted by |A|𝐴|A|, is the number of faces of the UIPQ contained in A𝐴A, and the boundary size of A𝐴A, denoted by |∂A|𝐴|\partial A|, is the number of edges in the boundary of A𝐴A.

Theorem 3.

Let δ>0𝛿0\delta>0. Then,

infA∈𝒦|∂A||A|14​(log⁡|A|)−34−δ>0,a.s.subscriptinfimum𝐴𝒦𝐴superscript𝐴14superscript𝐴34𝛿0a.s.\inf_{A\in\mathcal{K}}\frac{|\partial A|}{|A|^{\frac{1}{4}}\,(\log|A|)^{-\frac{3}{4}-\delta}}>0\;,\ \hbox{a.s.}

The exponent 3434\frac{3}{4} in the statement of the theorem is presumably not the optimal one. Our method involves estimates for the tail of the distribution of the volume of the hull Br∙​(𝒫)subscriptsuperscript𝐵∙𝑟𝒫B^{\bullet}_{r}({\mathcal{P}}), which are derived from a first moment bound (Proposition 15). We expect that these estimates can be improved, leading to a better value of the exponent of log⁡|A|𝐴\log|A| (the results of Riera [20] for the Brownian plane suggest that one should be able to replace 3434\frac{3}{4} by 1212\frac{1}{2} in the statement of the theorem). On the other hand, one cannot hope to replace |A|14​(log⁡|A|)−34−δsuperscript𝐴14superscript𝐴34𝛿|A|^{\frac{1}{4}}\,(\log|A|)^{-\frac{3}{4}-\delta} by |A|14superscript𝐴14|A|^{\frac{1}{4}} in the theorem: Simple zero-one arguments using the separating cycles introduced by Krikun [14] (see Section 2.4 below) show that there exist sets A𝐴A such that the ratio |∂A|/|A|14𝐴superscript𝐴14|\partial A|/|A|^{\frac{1}{4}} is arbitrarily small.

Still we can state the following proposition.

Proposition 4.

Let ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0. There exists a constant cε>0subscript𝑐𝜀0c_{\varepsilon}>0 such that, for every integer n≥1𝑛1n\geq 1, the property

|∂A|≥cε​n1/4,for every ​A∈𝒦​ such that ​|A|≥n,formulae-sequence𝐴subscript𝑐𝜀superscript𝑛14for every 𝐴𝒦 such that 𝐴𝑛|\partial A|\geq c_{\varepsilon}\,n^{1/4}\;,\quad\hbox{for every }A\in\mathcal{K}\hbox{ such that }|A|\geq n\;,

holds with probability at least 1−ε1𝜀1-\varepsilon.

As an immediate consequence of Proposition 4, we also get that, for every ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0 and every M>1𝑀1M>1, we can find a constant cε,M>0subscript𝑐𝜀𝑀0c_{\varepsilon,M}>0 such that, for every integer n≥1𝑛1n\geq 1,

ℙ​(infA∈𝒦,n≤|A|≤M​n|∂A||A|14≥cε,M)≥1−ε.ℙsubscriptinfimumformulae-sequence𝐴𝒦𝑛𝐴𝑀𝑛𝐴superscript𝐴14subscript𝑐𝜀𝑀1𝜀{\mathbb{P}}\Bigg{(}\inf_{A\in\mathcal{K},\,n\leq|A|\leq Mn}\frac{|\partial A|}{|A|^{\frac{1}{4}}}\geq c_{\varepsilon,M}\Bigg{)}\geq 1-\varepsilon.

Indeed, we just have to take cε,M=cε/M1/4subscript𝑐𝜀𝑀subscript𝑐𝜀superscript𝑀14c_{\varepsilon,M}=c_{\varepsilon}/M^{1/4}, with the notation of Proposition 4. But, as explained after the statement of Theorem 3, we cannot lift the constraint n≤|A|≤M​n𝑛𝐴𝑀𝑛n\leq|A|\leq Mn in the last display.

The proofs of both Theorem 3 and Proposition 4 rely on Theorem 1 and on the fact that the volume of the hull of radius r𝑟r is of order r4superscript𝑟4r^{4}. Assuming that |∂A|𝐴|\partial A| is small, then either the root vertex is sufficiently far from ∂A𝐴\partial A, which implies that a large ball centered at the root vertex is disconnected from infinity by the small cycle ∂A𝐴\partial A (so that we can use the estimate of Theorem 1) or the root vertex is close to ∂A𝐴\partial A, but then it follows that the whole set A𝐴A is contained in the standard hull of radius (approximately) equal to the distance from the root vertex to ∂A𝐴\partial A, which implies that the volume of A𝐴A cannot be too big (at this point of the argument, in the proof of Theorem 3, we need estimates for the tail of the distribution of the volume of hulls).

The paper is organized as follows. Section 2 presents a number of preliminaries, concerning truncated quadrangulations, their relations with the UIPQ and their skeleton decompositions, and a number of related calculations. As mentioned earlier, this section owes a lot to the work of Krikun [14], and in particular we make use of enumeration results derived in [14]. One additional motivation for deriving the results of Section 2 in a somewhat more precise form than in [14] is the fact that we plan to use these results in a forthcoming work [16] on local modifications of distances in the UIPQ, in the spirit of [8]. Proposition 2 is proved in Section 3, and part (i) of Theorem 1 easily follows from this proposition. Section 4 is devoted to the proof of part (ii) of Theorem 1. This proof relies on the explicit calculation of the distribution of the number of trees with maximal height in the forest coding the annulus 𝒞​(r,r′)𝒞𝑟superscript𝑟′\mathcal{C}(r,r^{\prime}) (Proposition 14). This calculation is also used to give an easy lower bound for the probability ℙ​(L​(R)≤ε​R)ℙ𝐿𝑅𝜀𝑅{\mathbb{P}}(L(R)\leq\varepsilon R). Section 5 contains the proof of Proposition 4 and Theorem 3. An important ingredient of the proof of Theorem 3 is Proposition 15, which provides a first moment bound for the volume of hulls. Finally, the Appendix gives the proof of a technical lemma stated at the end of Section 2, which plays an important role in Section 3.

2 Preliminaries

2.1 Truncated quadrangulations

We will consider truncated quadrangulations. Informally, these are quadrangulations with a simple boundary, where the quadrangles incident to the boundary are replaced by triangles. A more precise definition is as follows.

Definition 2.1.

Let p≥1𝑝1p\geq 1 be an integer. A truncated quadrangulation with boundary size p𝑝p is a planar map ℳℳ\mathcal{M} having a distinguished face 𝔣𝔣\mathfrak{f} with a simple boundary of size p𝑝p such that:

  1. ∙∙\bullet

    Each edge of the boundary of 𝔣𝔣\mathfrak{f} is incident both to 𝔣𝔣\mathfrak{f} and to a triangular face of ℳℳ\mathcal{M} and these triangular faces are distinct.

  2. ∙∙\bullet

    All faces other than 𝔣𝔣\mathfrak{f} and the triangular faces incident to the boundary of 𝔣𝔣\mathfrak{f} have degree 444.

It will be convenient to view truncated quadrangulations as drawn in the plane in such a way that the distinguished face is the unbounded face. With this convention, we will always assume that a truncated quadrangulation is rooted and, unless otherwise specified, that the root edge lies on the boundary of the distinguished face and is oriented clockwise. See Fig.2 for an example. Faces distinct from the distinguished face are called inner faces, and vertices that do not lie on the boundary of the distinguished face are called inner vertices.

Notice that, when p≥2𝑝2p\geq 2, any of the triangular faces incident to the boundary of 𝔣𝔣\mathfrak{f} must be nondegenerate (i.e. its boundary cannot contain a loop). Furthermore, a simple argument shows that each of these triangular faces is incident to an inner vertex. The last property clearly also holds if p=1𝑝1p=1. Hence a truncated quadrangulation with boundary size p≥1𝑝1p\geq 1 must have at least one inner vertex.

We notice that our truncated quadrangulations with boundary size p𝑝p are in one-to-one correspondence with the “quadrangulations with a simple boundary” of size 2​p2𝑝2p considered by Krikun [14] (starting from the latter, we just “cut” the boundary quadrangles along the appropriate diagonals to get a truncated quadrangulation). If we add an extra vertex v∗subscript𝑣v_{*} inside the face 𝔣𝔣\mathfrak{f}, then draw an edge from each vertex of the boundary of 𝔣𝔣\mathfrak{f} to v∗subscript𝑣v_{*}, and finally remove all edges of the boundary of 𝔣𝔣\mathfrak{f}, we get a plane quadrangulation and hence a bipartite graph: In particular, it follows that, if v𝑣v and v′superscript𝑣′v^{\prime} are two adjacent inner vertices of ℳℳ\mathcal{M}, their distances from the boundary differ by 111. This observation will be useful later.

For integers n≥1𝑛1n\geq 1 and p≥1𝑝1p\geq 1, we let ℚn,ptrsubscriptsuperscriptℚtr𝑛𝑝{\mathbb{Q}}^{\mathrm{tr}}_{n,p} be the set of all (rooted) truncated quadrangulations with boundary size p𝑝p and n𝑛n inner faces.

We need another definition.

Definition 2.2.

Let h,p,q≥1ℎ𝑝𝑞1h,p,q\geq 1 be positive integers. A truncated quadrangulation of the cylinder of height hℎh with boundary sizes (p,q)𝑝𝑞(p,q) is a planar map 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} having two distinguished faces 𝔣bsubscript𝔣𝑏\mathfrak{f}_{b} and 𝔣tsubscript𝔣𝑡\mathfrak{f}_{t} such that:

  1. ∙∙\bullet

    The face 𝔣bsubscript𝔣𝑏\mathfrak{f}_{b} (called the bottom face) has a simple boundary of size p𝑝p, which is called the bottom cycle, and the face 𝔣tsubscript𝔣𝑡\mathfrak{f}_{t} (called the top face) has a simple boundary of size q𝑞q, which is called the top cycle.

  2. ∙∙\bullet

    Each edge of the bottom cycle (resp. of the top cycle) is incident both to 𝔣bsubscript𝔣𝑏\mathfrak{f}_{b} (resp. to 𝔣tsubscript𝔣𝑡\mathfrak{f}_{t}) and to a triangular face of 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} and these triangular faces are distinct.

  3. ∙∙\bullet

    All faces other than 𝔣bsubscript𝔣𝑏\mathfrak{f}_{b}, 𝔣tsubscript𝔣𝑡\mathfrak{f}_{t}, and the triangular faces incident to the bottom and top cycles, have degree 444.

  4. ∙∙\bullet

    Every vertex of the top cycle is at graph distance exactly hℎh from the bottom cycle, and every edge of the top cycle is incident to a triangular face containing a vertex at graph distance h−1ℎ1h-1 from the bottom cycle.

By definition, the inner faces of 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} are all faces except the two distinguished ones. The last assertion of Definition 2.2 shows that the top face and the bottom face do not play a symmetric role. We will implicitly assume that truncated quadrangulations of the cylinder of height hℎh are drawn in the plane so that the top face is the unbounded face, and that they are rooted in such a way that the root edge lies on the bottom cycle and is oriented clockwise. See Fig.3 for an example.

In a way similar to the truncated quadrangulations of Definition 2.1, the triangular face associated with an edge of the bottom cycle must contain a vertex which does not belong to this cycle. The same holds for the top cycle — this is obvious from the last assertion of Definition 2.2.

2.2 Truncated quadrangulations in the UIPQ

Let us now explain why the definitions of the previous section are relevant to our study of the UIPQ. We label vertices of the UIPQ by their graph distance from the root vertex. Then the labels of corners incident to a face (enumerated in cyclic order along the boundary of the face) are of the type k,k−1,k,k−1𝑘𝑘1𝑘𝑘1k,k-1,k,k-1 or k,k+1,k,k−1𝑘𝑘1𝑘𝑘1k,k+1,k,k-1 for some integer k≥1𝑘1k\geq 1, and the face is called k𝑘k-simple in the second case. Fix an integer r≥1𝑟1r\geq 1. For every r𝑟r-simple face, we draw a diagonal between the two corners labeled r𝑟r in this face, and these diagonals are called r𝑟r-diagonals. If v𝑣v is a vertex incident to an r𝑟r-diagonal (equivalently, if v𝑣v has label r𝑟r and is incident to an r𝑟r-simple face), then a simple combinatorial argument shows that the number of r𝑟r-diagonals incident to v𝑣v is even — to be precise, we need to count this number with multiplicities, since r𝑟r-diagonals may be loops. It follows that the collection of all r𝑟r-diagonals can be obtained as the union of a collection of disjoint simple cycles (disjoint here means that no edge is shared by two of these cycles). See Fig.4 for an example.

Lemma 5.

There is a unique simple cycle made of r𝑟r-diagonals such that the unbounded component of the complement of this cycle contains no r𝑟r-diagonal and no vertex at distance less than or equal to r𝑟r from the root vertex. This cycle will be called the maximal cycle made of r𝑟r-diagonals and will be denoted by 𝒞rsubscript𝒞𝑟\mathcal{C}_{r}.

Proof.

It suffices to verify that the root vertex lies inside a bounded component of the complement of some cycle made of r𝑟r-diagonals (this cycle may be taken to be simple and then satisfies the properties stated in the lemma). To this end, consider a geodesic γ𝛾\gamma from the root vertex to infinity and write vrsubscript𝑣𝑟v_{r}, resp. vr−1,vr+1subscript𝑣𝑟1subscript𝑣𝑟1v_{r-1},v_{r+1}, for the unique vertex of γ𝛾\gamma at distance r𝑟r, resp. r−1,r+1𝑟1𝑟1r-1,r+1, from the root vertex. Also write vr​vr−1subscript𝑣𝑟subscript𝑣𝑟1{v_{r}v_{r-1}}, resp. vr​vr+1subscript𝑣𝑟subscript𝑣𝑟1{v_{r}v_{r+1}}, for the edge of γ𝛾\gamma incident to vrsubscript𝑣𝑟v_{r} and vr−1subscript𝑣𝑟1v_{r-1}, resp. to vrsubscript𝑣𝑟v_{r} and vr+1subscript𝑣𝑟1v_{r+1}. Let k1subscript𝑘1k_{1}, resp. k2subscript𝑘2k_{2}, denote the number of r𝑟r-diagonals incident to vrsubscript𝑣𝑟v_{r} that lie between vr​vr+1subscript𝑣𝑟subscript𝑣𝑟1{v_{r}v_{r+1}} and vr​vr−1subscript𝑣𝑟subscript𝑣𝑟1{v_{r}v_{r-1}}, resp. between vr​vr−1subscript𝑣𝑟subscript𝑣𝑟1{v_{r}v_{r-1}} and vr​vr+1subscript𝑣𝑟subscript𝑣𝑟1{v_{r}v_{r+1}}, when turning around vrsubscript𝑣𝑟v_{r} in clockwise order (self-loops are counted twice). An easy combinatorial argument shows that both k1subscript𝑘1k_{1} and k2subscript𝑘2k_{2} are odd. It follows that there must exist a cycle made of r𝑟r-diagonals that starts with an edge lying between vr​vr+1subscript𝑣𝑟subscript𝑣𝑟1{v_{r}v_{r+1}} and vr​vr−1subscript𝑣𝑟subscript𝑣𝑟1{v_{r}v_{r-1}} (in clockwise order) and ends with an edge lying between vr​vr−1subscript𝑣𝑟subscript𝑣𝑟1{v_{r}v_{r-1}} and vr​vr+1subscript𝑣𝑟subscript𝑣𝑟1{v_{r}v_{r+1}}. Simple topological considerations now show that the root vertex, and in fact the whole geodesic path γ𝛾\gamma up to vertex vr−1subscript𝑣𝑟1v_{r-1} must lie in a bounded component of the complement of this cycle. ∎

If we now add all edges of 𝒞rsubscript𝒞𝑟\mathcal{C}_{r} to the UIPQ and then remove all edges that lie in the unbounded component of the complement of 𝒞rsubscript𝒞𝑟\mathcal{C}_{r}, we get a truncated quadrangulation in the sense of Definition 2.1 (with the minor difference that, assuming that we keep the same root as in the UIPQ, the root edge does not belong to the boundary of the distinguished face). This truncated quadrangulation is called the truncated hull of radius r𝑟r and is denoted by ℋrtrsubscriptsuperscriptℋtr𝑟\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{tr}}_{r}. Its boundary size (the length of 𝒞rsubscript𝒞𝑟\mathcal{C}_{r}) is called the perimeter of the hull and denoted by Hrsubscript𝐻𝑟H_{r}. Notice that, by construction, any vertex belonging to the boundary of the distinguished face is at distance exactly r𝑟r from the root vertex. Furthermore, for any vertex v𝑣v of the UIPQ that does not belong to ℋrtrsubscriptsuperscriptℋtr𝑟\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{tr}}_{r} (equivalently, that lies in the unbounded component of the complement of 𝒞rsubscript𝒞𝑟\mathcal{C}_{r}) there exists a path going from v𝑣v to infinity that visits only vertices with label at least r𝑟r. This property follows from the fact that any two points of 𝒞rsubscript𝒞𝑟\mathcal{C}_{r} are connected by a path that visits only vertices with label at least r𝑟r.

We may and will sometimes view the truncated hull ℋrtrsubscriptsuperscriptℋtr𝑟\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{tr}}_{r} as a quadrangulation of the cylinder: To this end, we just split the root edge into a double edge, and insert a loop (based on the root vertex) inside the resulting 222-gon. This yields a truncated quadrangulation of the cylinder of height r𝑟r with boundary sizes (1,Hr)1subscript𝐻𝑟(1,H_{r}), whose top cycle is 𝒞rsubscript𝒞𝑟\mathcal{C}_{r}. The root edge is the inserted loop as required in our conventions. See Fig.5 for an illustration.

Similarly, if 1≤r<r′1𝑟superscript𝑟′1\leq r<r^{\prime}, we can consider the part of the UIPQ that lies between the cycles 𝒞rsubscript𝒞𝑟\mathcal{C}_{r} and 𝒞r′subscript𝒞superscript𝑟′\mathcal{C}_{r^{\prime}}. More precisely, we add all edges of 𝒞rsubscript𝒞𝑟\mathcal{C}_{r} and 𝒞r′subscript𝒞superscript𝑟′\mathcal{C}_{r^{\prime}} to the UIPQ and then remove all edges that lie either inside the cycle 𝒞rsubscript𝒞𝑟\mathcal{C}_{r} or outside the cycle 𝒞r′subscript𝒞superscript𝑟′\mathcal{C}_{r^{\prime}}. This gives rise to a quadrangulation of the cylinder of height r′−rsuperscript𝑟′𝑟r^{\prime}-r whose bottom cycle and top cycle are 𝒞rsubscript𝒞𝑟\mathcal{C}_{r} and 𝒞r′subscript𝒞superscript𝑟′\mathcal{C}_{r^{\prime}} respectively (we in fact need to specify the root edge on the bottom cycle, but we will come back to this later). By definition, this is the annulus 𝒞​(r,r′)𝒞𝑟superscript𝑟′\mathcal{C}(r,r^{\prime}). We can extend this definition to r=0𝑟0r=0: The annulus 𝒞​(0,r′)𝒞0superscript𝑟′\mathcal{C}(0,r^{\prime}) is just the truncated hull ℋr′trsubscriptsuperscriptℋtrsuperscript𝑟′\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{tr}}_{r^{\prime}} viewed as a quadrangulation of the cylinder (we can also say that it is the part of the UIPQ that lies between the cycles 𝒞0subscript𝒞0\mathcal{C}_{0} and 𝒞r′subscript𝒞superscript𝑟′\mathcal{C}_{r^{\prime}}, if 𝒞0subscript𝒞0\mathcal{C}_{0} consists of the loop added as explained above).

As an important remark, we note that the truncated hull of radius r𝑟r is quite different from the (usual) hull of radius r𝑟r considered e.g. in [6, 7], which is denoted by Br∙​(𝒫)subscriptsuperscript𝐵∙𝑟𝒫B^{\bullet}_{r}({\mathcal{P}}) and is obtained by filling in the bounded holes in the ball of radius r𝑟r (recall that the ball of radius r≥1𝑟1r\geq 1 is obtained as the union of all faces incident to at least one vertex whose graph distance from the root vertex is at most r−1𝑟1r-1). To avoid any ambiguity, the hull Br∙​(𝒫)subscriptsuperscript𝐵∙𝑟𝒫B^{\bullet}_{r}({\mathcal{P}}) will be called the standard hull of radius r𝑟r. The truncated hull can be recovered from the standard hull by considering the maximal cycle made of r𝑟r-diagonals as explained above. On the other hand, the standard hull is “bigger” than the truncated hull: To recover the standard hull from the truncated hull, we need to add the triangles incident to r𝑟r-diagonals that have been cut when removing the unbounded component of the complement of the maximal cycle, but also to fill in the bounded holes that may appear when adding these triangles (see Fig.4 for an example). For future use, we notice that the boundary of the standard hull Br∙​(𝒫)subscriptsuperscript𝐵∙𝑟𝒫B^{\bullet}_{r}({\mathcal{P}}) is a simple cycle, and that the graph distances of vertices in this cycle to the root vertex alternate between the values r𝑟r and r+1𝑟1r+1: Those vertices at graph distance r𝑟r also belong to the cycle 𝒞rsubscript𝒞𝑟\mathcal{C}_{r}, but in general there are other vertices of 𝒞rsubscript𝒞𝑟\mathcal{C}_{r} that do not belong to the boundary of Br∙​(𝒫)subscriptsuperscript𝐵∙𝑟𝒫B^{\bullet}_{r}({\mathcal{P}}) (see Fig.4).

2.3 The skeleton decomposition

We will now describe a decomposition of quadrangulations of the cylinder in layers. This is essentially due to Krikun [14] and very similar to the case of triangulations, which is treated in [13, 8]. For this reason, we will skip some details.

Let us fix a quadrangulation 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} of the cylinder of height h≥2ℎ2h\geq 2 with boundary sizes (p,q)𝑝𝑞(p,q). Assign to each vertex a label equal to its distance from the bottom boundary. Let k∈{1,2,…,h−1}𝑘12…ℎ1k\in\{1,2,\ldots,h-1\}, and consider all diagonals connecting corners labeled k𝑘k in k𝑘k-simple faces (defined in exactly the same manner as in the previous section for the UIPQ). As in the case of the UIPQ described above, these diagonals form a collection of cycles, and there is a maximal cycle which is simple and has the property that the unbounded component of the complement of this cycle contains no vertex with label less than or equal to k𝑘k. Define the hull ℋk​(𝒬)subscriptℋ𝑘𝒬\mathcal{H}_{k}(\mathcal{Q}) by first adding to 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} the edges of this maximal cycle and then removing all edges that lie in the unbounded component of the complement of the maximal cycle. We obtain a quadrangulation of the cylinder of height k𝑘k with boundary sizes (p,qk)𝑝subscript𝑞𝑘(p,q_{k}), where qksubscript𝑞𝑘q_{k} denotes the size of the maximal cycle. We write ℋktr​(𝒬)subscriptsuperscriptℋtr𝑘𝒬\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{tr}}_{k}(\mathcal{Q}) for this quadrangulation of the cylinder, and ∂k𝒬subscript𝑘𝒬\partial_{k}\mathcal{Q} for its top cycle , so that qk=|∂k𝒬|subscript𝑞𝑘subscript𝑘𝒬q_{k}=|\partial_{k}\mathcal{Q}|. See Fig.3 for the cycles ∂k𝒬subscript𝑘𝒬\partial_{k}\mathcal{Q} in a particular example.

Suppose now that we add to 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} all diagonals drawn in the previous procedure, for every 1≤k≤h−11𝑘ℎ11\leq k\leq h-1 (in other words, we add the cycles ∂k𝒬subscript𝑘𝒬\partial_{k}\mathcal{Q} for every 1≤k≤h−11𝑘ℎ11\leq k\leq h-1), and write 𝒬∙superscript𝒬∙\mathcal{Q}^{\bullet} for the resulting planar map (whose faces, except for the two distinguished faces of 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}, are either quadrangles or triangles). For every 1≤k≤h1𝑘ℎ1\leq k\leq h, the k𝑘k-th layer of 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} is obtained as the part of 𝒬∙superscript𝒬∙\mathcal{Q}^{\bullet} that lies between the cycles ∂k−1𝒬subscript𝑘1𝒬\partial_{k-1}\mathcal{Q} and ∂k𝒬subscript𝑘𝒬\partial_{k}\mathcal{Q}, where by convention ∂0𝒬subscript0𝒬\partial_{0}\mathcal{Q} is the bottom cycle of 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} and ∂h𝒬subscriptℎ𝒬\partial_{h}\mathcal{Q} is the top cycle. We can view this layer as a quadrangulation of the cylinder of height 111 with boundary sizes (|∂k−1𝒬|,|∂k𝒬|)subscript𝑘1𝒬subscript𝑘𝒬(|\partial_{k-1}\mathcal{Q}|,|\partial_{k}\mathcal{Q}|) (except that we have not specified the choice of the root edge — we will come back to this later in the case of interest to us).

We will now introduce an unordered forest ℱ​(𝒬)ℱ𝒬\mathcal{F}(\mathcal{Q}) of (rooted) plane trees that in some sense describes the configuration of layers. First note that, for every 1≤k≤h1𝑘ℎ1\leq k\leq h, each edge of ∂k𝒬subscript𝑘𝒬\partial_{k}\mathcal{Q} is incident to a unique triangle of 𝒬∙superscript𝒬∙\mathcal{Q}^{\bullet} whose third vertex lies on ∂k−1𝒬subscript𝑘1𝒬\partial_{k-1}\mathcal{Q} (when k=h𝑘ℎk=h, this is a consequence of the last assertion of Definition 2.2, and when k<h𝑘ℎk<h this follows from the way we constructed the triangles incident to the top boundary of ℋktr​(𝒬)subscriptsuperscriptℋtr𝑘𝒬\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{tr}}_{k}(\mathcal{Q})). We call such triangles downward triangles of 𝒬∙superscript𝒬∙\mathcal{Q}^{\bullet} (see the left side of Fig.6). The forest ℱ​(𝒬)ℱ𝒬\mathcal{F}(\mathcal{Q}) consists of exactly q𝑞q trees, each tree being associated with an edge of ∂h𝒬subscriptℎ𝒬\partial_{h}\mathcal{Q}. The vertex set of the forest is the collection of all edges of ∂k𝒬subscript𝑘𝒬\partial_{k}\mathcal{Q}, for 0≤k≤h0𝑘ℎ0\leq k\leq h. The genealogical relation is specified as follows: The roots of the trees are the edges of ∂h𝒬subscriptℎ𝒬\partial_{h}\mathcal{Q}, and, for every k∈{0,…,h−1}𝑘0…ℎ1k\in\{0,\ldots,h-1\}, an edge e𝑒e of ∂k𝒬subscript𝑘𝒬\partial_{k}\mathcal{Q} is a “child” of an edge e′superscript𝑒′e^{\prime} of ∂k+1𝒬subscript𝑘1𝒬\partial_{k+1}\mathcal{Q} if and only if the downward triangle associated with e′superscript𝑒′e^{\prime} (i.e., containing e′superscript𝑒′e^{\prime} in its boundary) is the first one that one encounters when turning around ∂k−1𝒬subscript𝑘1𝒬\partial_{k-1}\mathcal{Q} in clockwise order, starting from the middle of the edge e𝑒e. This definition should be clear from the right side of Fig.6. Notice that edges of ∂k𝒬subscript𝑘𝒬\partial_{k}\mathcal{Q} correspond to vertices of the forest ℱ​(𝒬)ℱ𝒬\mathcal{F}(\mathcal{Q}) at generation h−kℎ𝑘h-k, for every 0≤k≤h0𝑘ℎ0\leq k\leq h. The planar structure of each tree in the forest is obviously induced by the planar structure of 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}, see again Fig.6.

We note that the root edge of 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} is a vertex of ℱ​(𝒬)ℱ𝒬\mathcal{F}(\mathcal{Q}) at generation hℎh and belongs to one of the trees of ℱ​(𝒬)ℱ𝒬\mathcal{F}(\mathcal{Q}), which we denote by τ1subscript𝜏1\tau_{1}. We may then write τ2,…,τqsubscript𝜏2…subscript𝜏𝑞\tau_{2},\ldots,\tau_{q} for the other trees of of ℱ​(𝒬)ℱ𝒬\mathcal{F}(\mathcal{Q}) listed in clockwise order from τ1subscript𝜏1\tau_{1}. Without risk of confusion, we keep the notation ℱ​(𝒬)ℱ𝒬\mathcal{F}(\mathcal{Q}) for the ordered forest (τ1,…,τq)subscript𝜏1…subscript𝜏𝑞(\tau_{1},\ldots,\tau_{q}).

The ordered forest ℱ​(𝒬)ℱ𝒬\mathcal{F}(\mathcal{Q}) characterizes the combinatorial structure of the downward triangles in 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}. To determine 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} completely, one also needs to specify the way “slots” between two successive downward triangles in a given layer are filled in. More precisely, let e𝑒e be an edge of ∂k𝒬subscript𝑘𝒬\partial_{k}\mathcal{Q}, for some 1≤k≤h1𝑘ℎ1\leq k\leq h, and let e~~𝑒\tilde{e} be the edge of ∂k𝒬subscript𝑘𝒬\partial_{k}\mathcal{Q} preceding e𝑒e in clockwise order (we discuss below the case when there is only one edge in ∂k𝒬subscript𝑘𝒬\partial_{k}\mathcal{Q}). The part of the k𝑘k-th layer of 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} between the downward triangle associated with e~~𝑒\tilde{e} and the downward triangle associated with e𝑒e produces a slot with perimeter ce+2subscript𝑐𝑒2c_{e}+2, where cesubscript𝑐𝑒c_{e} is the number of children of e𝑒e in the forest ℱ​(𝒬)ℱ𝒬\mathcal{F}(\mathcal{Q}). This slot is said to be associated with e𝑒e (it is also incident to a unique vertex v𝑣v of ∂k𝒬subscript𝑘𝒬\partial_{k}\mathcal{Q}). See the left side of Fig.7 for an illustration. If ce=0subscript𝑐𝑒0c_{e}=0, it may happen that the slot is empty, if the downward triangles associated with e~~𝑒\tilde{e} and e𝑒e are adjacent. Also notice that when |∂k𝒬|=1subscript𝑘𝒬1|\partial_{k}\mathcal{Q}|=1, the only edge of ∂k𝒬subscript𝑘𝒬\partial_{k}\mathcal{Q} is a loop, but there is still an associated slot, which is bounded by the double edge in the boundary of the downward triangle associated with the unique edge of ∂k𝒬subscript𝑘𝒬\partial_{k}\mathcal{Q}, and the edges of ∂k−1𝒬subscript𝑘1𝒬\partial_{k-1}\mathcal{Q}.

The boundary of the slot associated with e𝑒e is of the type pictured in the left side of Fig.7, where there are cesubscript𝑐𝑒c_{e} horizontal edges and the two non-horizontal edges are incident to the downward triangles associated with e~~𝑒\tilde{e} and e𝑒e. Strictly speaking, the random planar map consisting of the part of 𝒬∙superscript𝒬∙\mathcal{Q}^{\bullet} in the slot is not a truncated quadrangulation with a boundary, but a simple transformation allows us to view it as a truncated quadrangulation with a boundary of size ce~+1subscript𝑐~𝑒1c_{\tilde{e}}+1: this transformation, which involves adding an extra edge, is illustrated in Fig.7 (see also Fig.6 in [14]) — to be precise, one should notice that the two vertices a𝑎a and b𝑏b in Fig.7 may be the same if all edges of ∂k−1𝒬subscript𝑘1𝒬\partial_{k-1}\mathcal{Q} have the same “parent” in ∂k𝒬subscript𝑘𝒬\partial_{k}\mathcal{Q}, but our interpretation still goes through. There is therefore a one-to-one correspondence between possible fillings of the slot and such truncated quadrangulations. To make this correspondence precise, we need a convention for the position of the root: we can declare that in the filling of the slot, the root edge of the truncated quadrangulation corresponds to the added extra edge. We notice that, in the special case where ce=0subscript𝑐𝑒0c_{e}=0, if the truncated quadrangulation used to fill in the slot is the unique truncated quadrangulation with boundary size 111 and no quadrangle, this means that the slot is empty so that two sides of the downward triangles associated with e~~𝑒\tilde{e} and e𝑒e are glued together.

Following [8], we say that a forest ℱℱ\mathcal{F} with a distinguished vertex is (h,p,q)ℎ𝑝𝑞(h,p,q)-admissible if

  1. (i)

    the forest consists of an ordered sequence (𝒯1,𝒯2,…,𝒯q)subscript𝒯1subscript𝒯2…subscript𝒯𝑞({\mathcal{T}}_{1},{\mathcal{T}}_{2},\ldots,{\mathcal{T}}_{q}) of q𝑞q (rooted) plane trees,

  2. (ii)

    the maximal height of these trees is hℎh,

  3. (iii)

    the total number of vertices of the forest at generation hℎh is p𝑝p,

  4. (iv)

    the distinguished vertex has height hℎh and belongs to 𝒯1subscript𝒯1{\mathcal{T}}_{1}.

If ℱℱ\mathcal{F} is a (h,p,q)ℎ𝑝𝑞(h,p,q)-admissible forest, we write ℱ∗superscriptℱ\mathcal{F}^{*} for the set all vertices of ℱℱ\mathcal{F} at height strictly less than hℎh. We write 𝔽h,p,q∘subscriptsuperscript𝔽ℎ𝑝𝑞{\mathbb{F}}^{\circ}_{h,p,q} for the set of all (h,p,q)ℎ𝑝𝑞(h,p,q)-admissible forests.

The preceding discussion yields a bijection between, on the one hand, truncated quadrangulations 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} of the cylinder of height hℎh with boundary sizes (p,q)𝑝𝑞(p,q), and, on the other hand, pairs consisting of a (h,p,q)ℎ𝑝𝑞(h,p,q)-admissible forest ℱℱ\mathcal{F} and a collection (Mv)v∈ℱ∗subscriptsubscript𝑀𝑣𝑣superscriptℱ(M_{v})_{v\in\mathcal{F}^{*}} such that, for every v∈ℱ∗𝑣superscriptℱv\in\mathcal{F}^{*}, Mvsubscript𝑀𝑣M_{v} is a truncated quadrangulation with boundary size cv+1subscript𝑐𝑣1c_{v}+1, if cvsubscript𝑐𝑣c_{v} stands for the number of children of v𝑣v in ℱℱ\mathcal{F}. We call this bijection the skeleton decomposition and we say that ℱℱ\mathcal{F} is the skeleton of the quadrangulation 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}.

It will also be convenient to use the notation 𝔽h,p,qsubscript𝔽ℎ𝑝𝑞{\mathbb{F}}_{h,p,q} for the set of all (ordered) forests, with no distinguished vertex, that satisfy properties (i),(ii),(iii) above. If ℱ∈𝔽h,p,qℱsubscript𝔽ℎ𝑝𝑞\mathcal{F}\in{\mathbb{F}}_{h,p,q}, we keep the notation ℱ∗superscriptℱ\mathcal{F}^{*} for the set all vertices of ℱℱ\mathcal{F} at height strictly less than hℎh.

We also set, for every p≥1𝑝1p\geq 1, h≥1ℎ1h\geq 1,

𝔽h,p∘=⋃q≥1𝔽h,p,q∘,𝔽h,p=⋃q≥1𝔽h,p,q.formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝔽ℎ𝑝subscript𝑞1subscriptsuperscript𝔽ℎ𝑝𝑞subscript𝔽ℎ𝑝subscript𝑞1subscript𝔽ℎ𝑝𝑞{\mathbb{F}}^{\circ}_{h,p}=\bigcup_{q\geq 1}{\mathbb{F}}^{\circ}_{h,p,q}\;,\qquad{\mathbb{F}}_{h,p}=\bigcup_{q\geq 1}{\mathbb{F}}_{h,p,q}.

We conclude this section with a useful observation about connections between the truncated hull and the standard hull of the UIPQ. Consider two integers u𝑢u and r𝑟r with 1≤u<r1𝑢𝑟1\leq u<r. Recall that the truncated hull ℋrtrsubscriptsuperscriptℋtr𝑟\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{tr}}_{r} is viewed as a truncated quadrangulation of the cylinder of height r𝑟r, whose top cycle is 𝒞rsubscript𝒞𝑟\mathcal{C}_{r}. Write ℱ(r)∘subscriptsuperscriptℱ𝑟\mathcal{F}^{\circ}_{(r)} for the skeleton of this truncated quadrangulation, and also consider the cycle ∂uℋrtrsubscript𝑢subscriptsuperscriptℋtr𝑟\partial_{u}\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{tr}}_{r}, which by construction coincides with 𝒞usubscript𝒞𝑢\mathcal{C}_{u}. Vertices of this cycle are at distance u𝑢u from the root vertex of the UIPQ, and may or may not belong to the boundary of the standard hull of radius u𝑢u. However, assuming that |𝒞u|>1subscript𝒞𝑢1|\mathcal{C}_{u}|>1, if a vertex v𝑣v of the cycle 𝒞usubscript𝒞𝑢\mathcal{C}_{u} is such that the parents (in the forest ℱ(r)∘subscriptsuperscriptℱ𝑟\mathcal{F}^{\circ}_{(r)}) of the two edges of 𝒞u=∂uℋrtrsubscript𝒞𝑢subscript𝑢subscriptsuperscriptℋtr𝑟\mathcal{C}_{u}=\partial_{u}\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{tr}}_{r} incident to v𝑣v are different edges of the cycle 𝒞u+1=∂u+1ℋrtrsubscript𝒞𝑢1subscript𝑢1subscriptsuperscriptℋtr𝑟\mathcal{C}_{u+1}=\partial_{u+1}\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{tr}}_{r}, then v𝑣v must belong to the boundary of the standard hull of radius u𝑢u. We leave the easy verification of this combinatorial fact to the reader. Notice that this is only a sufficient condition and that vertices of 𝒞usubscript𝒞𝑢\mathcal{C}_{u} that do not satisfy this condition may also belong to the boundary of the standard hull of radius u𝑢u.

2.4 Geodesics in the skeleton decomposition

Consider again a quadrangulation 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} of the cylinder of height h≥2ℎ2h\geq 2 with boundary sizes (p,q)𝑝𝑞(p,q). Let v𝑣v be a vertex of ∂k𝒬subscript𝑘𝒬\partial_{k}\mathcal{Q} for some k∈{1,…,h}𝑘1…ℎk\in\{1,\ldots,h\}. We assume that |∂k𝒬|≥2subscript𝑘𝒬2|\partial_{k}\mathcal{Q}|\geq 2. Then v𝑣v is incident to two downward triangles which both contain an edge of ∂k𝒬subscript𝑘𝒬\partial_{k}\mathcal{Q} and a vertex of ∂k−1𝒬subscript𝑘1𝒬\partial_{k-1}\mathcal{Q}. Each of these triangles has an edge incident both to v𝑣v and to a vertex of ∂k−1𝒬subscript𝑘1𝒬\partial_{k-1}\mathcal{Q}, and these two edges (which may be the same if the slot incident to v𝑣v in the k𝑘k-th layer of 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} is empty) are called downward edges from v𝑣v. If the slot incident to v𝑣v is nonempty we can in fact define the left downward edge by declaring that it is the first (downward) edge visited when exploring the boundary of the slot in clockwise order starting from a point of ∂k−1𝒬subscript𝑘1𝒬\partial_{k-1}\mathcal{Q}, and the other downward edge is called the right downward edge (of course if the slot is empty, the left and right downward edges coincide). We leave it to the reader to adapt these definitions in the case |∂k𝒬|=1subscript𝑘𝒬1|\partial_{k}\mathcal{Q}|=1 — in that case the left and right downward edges form a double edge.

We then define the left downward geodesic from v𝑣v by saying that we first follow the left downward edge from v𝑣v to arrive at a vertex v′superscript𝑣′v^{\prime} of ∂k−1𝒬subscript𝑘1𝒬\partial_{k-1}\mathcal{Q}, then the left downward edge from v′superscript𝑣′v^{\prime} to a vertex v′′superscript𝑣′′v^{\prime\prime} of ∂k−2𝒬subscript𝑘2𝒬\partial_{k-2}\mathcal{Q}, and so on until we reach the bottom cycle ∂0𝒬subscript0𝒬\partial_{0}\mathcal{Q}. Similarly we define the right downward geodesic from v𝑣v by choosing at the first step the right downward edge from v𝑣v, but then, as previously, following left downward edges from the visited vertices. See Fig.8 for an illustration.

Let N𝑁N be the number of trees with maximal height in the skeleton decomposition of 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}. Assume that N≥2𝑁2N\geq 2, which implies that |∂k𝒬|≥2subscript𝑘𝒬2|\partial_{k}\mathcal{Q}|\geq 2 for every k∈{0,1,…,h}𝑘01…ℎk\in\{0,1,\ldots,h\}. Let e𝑒e be an edge of ∂h𝒬subscriptℎ𝒬\partial_{h}\mathcal{Q} corresponding to a tree with maximal height, and let v𝑣v be the first vertex incident to e𝑒e in clockwise order around ∂h𝒬subscriptℎ𝒬\partial_{h}\mathcal{Q}. Then the left downward geodesic (resp. the right downward geodesic) from v𝑣v hits the bottom cycle at a vertex v1subscript𝑣1v_{1} (resp. at v2subscript𝑣2v_{2}) such that the edges of the bottom cycle lying between v1subscript𝑣1v_{1} and v2subscript𝑣2v_{2} in clockwise order are exactly the descendants of e𝑒e at generation hℎh in the skeleton decomposition. See Fig.8 for an example. The concatenation of these two geodesic paths gives a path from v1subscript𝑣1v_{1} to v2subscript𝑣2v_{2} with length 2​h2ℎ2h. If we vary the edge e𝑒e among all roots of trees with maximal height, we can concatenate the resulting paths to get a cycle 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} with length 2​N​h2𝑁ℎ2Nh, such that any path from the bottom cycle to the top cycle must visit a vertex of 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}. In particular, if 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} is the annulus 𝒞​(R,R+h)𝒞𝑅𝑅ℎ\mathcal{C}(R,R+h) in the UIPQ, with R≥3𝑅3R\geq 3, the cycle 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} disconnects the ball BR−2​(𝒫)subscript𝐵𝑅2𝒫B_{R-2}({\mathcal{P}}) (or the hull BR−2∙​(𝒫)subscriptsuperscript𝐵∙𝑅2𝒫B^{\bullet}_{R-2}({\mathcal{P}})) from infinity.

2.5 Enumeration

We rely on the results of Krikun [14]. Recall that ℚn,ptrsubscriptsuperscriptℚtr𝑛𝑝{\mathbb{Q}}^{\mathrm{tr}}_{n,p} is the set of all truncated quadrangulations with boundary size p𝑝p and n𝑛n inner faces (this set is empty if n<p𝑛𝑝n<p).

U​(x,y)=∑p=1∞∑n=1∞#​ℚn,ptr​xn​yp.𝑈𝑥𝑦superscriptsubscript𝑝1superscriptsubscript𝑛1#subscriptsuperscriptℚtr𝑛𝑝superscript𝑥𝑛superscript𝑦𝑝U(x,y)=\sum_{p=1}^{\infty}\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\#{\mathbb{Q}}^{\mathrm{tr}}_{n,p}\ x^{n}y^{p}.

We will not need this formula, but we record the special case

U​(112,y)=124​(18−y)​(2−y)3−12+y2−y224,𝑈112𝑦12418𝑦superscript2𝑦312𝑦2superscript𝑦224U(\frac{1}{12},y)=\frac{1}{24}\sqrt{(18-y)(2-y)^{3}}-\frac{1}{2}+\frac{y}{2}-\frac{y^{2}}{24}, (1)

for 0≤y<20𝑦20\leq y<2.

As a consequence of the explicit formula for the generating function U𝑈U, we have, for every fixed p≥1𝑝1p\geq 1,

2.6 The distribution of hulls

Fix integers n𝑛n and p𝑝p with n≥p𝑛𝑝n\geq p. Let 𝒬p(n)subscriptsuperscript𝒬𝑛𝑝\mathcal{Q}^{(n)}_{p} be uniformly distributed over ℚn,ptrsubscriptsuperscriptℚtr𝑛𝑝{\mathbb{Q}}^{\mathrm{tr}}_{n,p} and given with a distinguished vertex chosen uniformly at random. Let r≥1𝑟1r\geq 1. If the height (distance from the boundary) of this distinguished vertex is at least r+1𝑟1r+1, we can make sense of the hull ℋr​(𝒬p(n))subscriptℋ𝑟subscriptsuperscript𝒬𝑛𝑝\mathcal{H}_{r}(\mathcal{Q}^{(n)}_{p}). To this end, we label each vertex by its graph distance from the boundary of the distinguished face, and we proceed in a way very similar to the case of the UIPQ discussed in Section 2.2. We consider all diagonals connecting corners labeled r𝑟r in r𝑟r-simple faces (of type r−1,r,r+1,r𝑟1𝑟𝑟1𝑟r-1,r,r+1,r), and the maximal cycle made of these diagonals, which has the property that the connected component of the complement of this cycle containing the distinguished vertex contains only vertices whose label is greater than r𝑟r. We then add to 𝒬p(n)subscriptsuperscript𝒬𝑛𝑝\mathcal{Q}^{(n)}_{p} the edges of this maximal cycle, and remove all edges lying in the connected component of the complement of this cycle containing the distinguished vertex. In this way, we obtain the hull ℋr​(𝒬p(n))subscriptℋ𝑟subscriptsuperscript𝒬𝑛𝑝\mathcal{H}_{r}(\mathcal{Q}^{(n)}_{p}), and it is easy to verify that ℋr​(𝒬p(n))subscriptℋ𝑟subscriptsuperscript𝒬𝑛𝑝\mathcal{H}_{r}(\mathcal{Q}^{(n)}_{p}) is a quadrangulation of the cylinder of height r𝑟r (the size of its bottom cycle is p𝑝p). If the height of the distinguished vertex is smaller than or equal to r𝑟r, the preceding definition no longer makes sense, but by convention we define ℋr​(𝒬p(n))=†subscriptℋ𝑟subscriptsuperscript𝒬𝑛𝑝†\mathcal{H}_{r}(\mathcal{Q}^{(n)}_{p})=\dagger to be some “cemetery point” added to the set of all quadrangulations of the cylinder of height r𝑟r.

The next lemma, which is an analog of Lemma 2 in [8], shows that the distribution of ℋr​(𝒬p(n))subscriptℋ𝑟subscriptsuperscript𝒬𝑛𝑝\mathcal{H}_{r}(\mathcal{Q}^{(n)}_{p}) has a limit when n→∞→𝑛n\to\infty. We let 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} be a fixed quadrangulation of the cylinder of height r𝑟r with boundary sizes (p,q)𝑝𝑞(p,q). This quadrangulation is coded by an (r,p,q)𝑟𝑝𝑞(r,p,q)-admissible forest ℱℱ\mathcal{F} and a collection (Mv)c∈ℱ∗subscriptsubscript𝑀𝑣𝑐superscriptℱ(M_{v})_{c\in\mathcal{F}^{*}}, such that, for every v∈ℱ∗𝑣superscriptℱv\in\mathcal{F}^{*}, Mvsubscript𝑀𝑣M_{v} is a truncated quadrangulation with boundary size cv+1subscript𝑐𝑣1c_{v}+1. Let 𝖨𝗇𝗇​(Mv)𝖨𝗇𝗇subscript𝑀𝑣\mathsf{Inn}(M_{v}) denote the number of inner faces of Mvsubscript𝑀𝑣M_{v}.

Remark. The offspring distribution θ𝜃\theta appears in the seemingly different context of labeled trees. Consider a critical Galton-Watson tree with geometric offspring distribution with parameter 1/2121/2. Given the tree, assign labels to vertices by declaring that the label of the root is 00 and that label increments on different edges are independent and uniformly distributed over {−1,0,1}101\{-1,0,1\}. Let N𝑁N be the number of vertices labeled −11-1 whose (strict) ancestors all have nonnegative labels. Then N𝑁N is distributed according to θ𝜃\theta (see [9, Proof of Theorem 5.2]). Via Schaeffer’s bijection relating plane quadrangulations to labeled trees, this interpretation of θ𝜃\theta is in fact closely related to Lemma 6.

From this explicit formula and (6), the desired identity (11) follows at once.

Once we know that μr,psubscript𝜇𝑟𝑝\mu_{r,p} is a probability distribution on 𝔽r,psubscript𝔽𝑟𝑝{\mathbb{F}}_{r,p}, the fact that μr,p∘subscriptsuperscript𝜇𝑟𝑝\mu^{\circ}_{r,p} is a probability distribution on 𝔽r,p∘subscriptsuperscript𝔽𝑟𝑝{\mathbb{F}}^{\circ}_{r,p} follows easily. First note that

μ~​((ℱ,v)):=1p​μr,p​(ℱ)assign~𝜇ℱ𝑣1𝑝subscript𝜇𝑟𝑝ℱ\tilde{\mu}((\mathcal{F},v)):=\frac{1}{p}\,\mu_{r,p}(\mathcal{F})

defines a probability distribution on the set of all pairs (ℱ,v)ℱ𝑣(\mathcal{F},v) consisting of a forest ℱ∈𝔽r,pℱsubscript𝔽𝑟𝑝\mathcal{F}\in{\mathbb{F}}_{r,p} and a distinguished vertex v𝑣v of ℱℱ\mathcal{F} at generation r𝑟r. Then notice that μr,p∘subscriptsuperscript𝜇𝑟𝑝\mu^{\circ}_{r,p} is just the push forward of μ~~𝜇\tilde{\mu} under the mapping (ℱ,v)↦ℱ′maps-toℱ𝑣superscriptℱ′(\mathcal{F},v)\mapsto\mathcal{F}^{\prime}, where ℱ′superscriptℱ′\mathcal{F}^{\prime} is obtained by circularly permuting the trees of ℱℱ\mathcal{F} so that v𝑣v belongs to the first tree of the forest. This completes the proof. ∎

Let us consider now the UIPQ. Recall our notation ℋrtrsubscriptsuperscriptℋtr𝑟\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{tr}}_{r} for the truncated hull of radius r𝑟r, and Hrsubscript𝐻𝑟H_{r} for the perimeter of ℋrtrsubscriptsuperscriptℋtr𝑟\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{tr}}_{r}, which is also the length of the cycle 𝒞rsubscript𝒞𝑟\mathcal{C}_{r}. For every r,p≥1𝑟𝑝1r,p\geq 1, let ℂr,psubscriptℂ𝑟𝑝{\mathbb{C}}_{r,p} be the set of all truncated quadrangulations of the cylinder of height r𝑟r with bottom boundary size p𝑝p and arbitrary top boundary size. If 𝒬∈ℂr,p𝒬subscriptℂ𝑟𝑝\mathcal{Q}\in{\mathbb{C}}_{r,p} and the size of the top boundary of 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} is q𝑞q, we set

Δr,p​(𝒬)=2q​κq2p​κp​∏v∈ℱ∗(θ​(cv)​12−𝖨𝗇𝗇​(Mv)Z​(cv+1)),subscriptΔ𝑟𝑝𝒬superscript2𝑞subscript𝜅𝑞superscript2𝑝subscript𝜅𝑝subscriptproduct𝑣superscriptℱ𝜃subscript𝑐𝑣superscript12𝖨𝗇𝗇subscript𝑀𝑣𝑍subscript𝑐𝑣1\Delta_{r,p}(\mathcal{Q})=\frac{2^{q}\kappa_{q}}{2^{p}\kappa_{p}}\,\prod_{v\in\mathcal{F}^{*}}\Bigg{(}\theta(c_{v})\,\frac{12^{-\mathsf{Inn}(M_{v})}}{Z(c_{v}+1)}\Bigg{)},

where (ℱ,(Mv)v∈ℱ∗)ℱsubscriptsubscript𝑀𝑣𝑣superscriptℱ(\mathcal{F},(M_{v})_{v\in\mathcal{F}^{*}}) is the skeleton decomposition of 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}.

Corollary 8.

Δr,psubscriptΔ𝑟𝑝\Delta_{r,p} is a probability measure on ℂr,psubscriptℂ𝑟𝑝{\mathbb{C}}_{r,p}. Furthermore, the distribution of ℋrtrsubscriptsuperscriptℋtr𝑟\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{tr}}_{r} is Δr,1subscriptΔ𝑟1\Delta_{r,1}.

Proof.

The fact that Δr,psubscriptΔ𝑟𝑝\Delta_{r,p} is a probability measure on ℂr,psubscriptℂ𝑟𝑝{\mathbb{C}}_{r,p} readily follows from the second assertion of Lemma 7, noting that, by the very definition of Z​(k)𝑍𝑘Z(k), we have

∑n=1∞#​ℚn,k+1tr​12−nZ​(k+1)=1.superscriptsubscript𝑛1#subscriptsuperscriptℚtr𝑛𝑘1superscript12𝑛𝑍𝑘11\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\#{\mathbb{Q}}^{\mathrm{tr}}_{n,k+1}\,\frac{12^{-n}}{Z(k+1)}=1.

To get the second assertion of the corollary, let ℚnsubscriptℚ𝑛{\mathbb{Q}}_{n} stand for the set of all (rooted) planar quadrangulations with n𝑛n faces. Via the transformation that consists in splitting the root edge to get a double edge, and then inserting a loop inside the resulting 222-gon (as in Fig.5), the set ℚnsubscriptℚ𝑛{\mathbb{Q}}_{n} is canonically identified to ℚn+1,1trsubscriptsuperscriptℚtr𝑛11{\mathbb{Q}}^{\mathrm{tr}}_{n+1,1}. From the local convergence of planar quadrangulations to the UIPQ [14], we deduce that the distribution of the hull of radius r𝑟r in a uniformly distributed quadrangulation in ℚn,1trsubscriptsuperscriptℚtr𝑛1{\mathbb{Q}}^{\mathrm{tr}}_{n,1} (equipped with a distinguished uniformly distributed vertex) converges to the distribution of the hull of radius r𝑟r in the UIPQ. The second assertion of the corollary now follows from Lemma 6. ∎

Corollary 9.

The distribution of Hrsubscript𝐻𝑟H_{r} is given by

ℙ​(Hr=p)=h​(p)h​(1)​ℙp​(Yr=1),p≥1,formulae-sequenceℙsubscript𝐻𝑟𝑝ℎ𝑝ℎ1subscriptℙ𝑝subscript𝑌𝑟1𝑝1{\mathbb{P}}(H_{r}=p)=\frac{h(p)}{h(1)}\,{\mathbb{P}}_{p}(Y_{r}=1),\quad p\geq 1,

where (Yn)n≥0subscriptsubscript𝑌𝑛𝑛0(Y_{n})_{n\geq 0} denotes a Galton-Watson branching process with offspring distribution θ𝜃\theta that starts from p𝑝p under the probability measure ℙpsubscriptℙ𝑝{\mathbb{P}}_{p}.

Proof.

Let ℱ(r)∘superscriptsubscriptℱ𝑟\mathcal{F}_{(r)}^{\circ} be the skeleton of the hull ℋrtrsubscriptsuperscriptℋtr𝑟\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{tr}}_{r} viewed as a quadrangulation of the cylinder of height r𝑟r. As a direct consequence of the second assertion of Corollary 8, ℱ(r)∘superscriptsubscriptℱ𝑟\mathcal{F}_{(r)}^{\circ} is distributed as μr,1∘subscriptsuperscript𝜇𝑟1\mu^{\circ}_{r,1}. Define ℱ(r)subscriptℱ𝑟\mathcal{F}_{(r)} from ℱ(r)∘subscriptsuperscriptℱ𝑟\mathcal{F}^{\circ}_{(r)} by “forgetting” the distinguished vertex and applying a uniform random circular permutation to the trees in the sequence. Arguing as in the end of the proof of Lemma 7, it follows that ℱ(r)subscriptℱ𝑟\mathcal{F}_{(r)} is distributed according to μr,1subscript𝜇𝑟1\mu_{r,1}.

Since Hrsubscript𝐻𝑟H_{r} is just the number of trees in the forest ℱ(r)subscriptℱ𝑟\mathcal{F}_{(r)}, we have

ℙ​(Hr=p)=∑ℱ∈𝔽r,1,pℙ​(ℱ(r)=ℱ)=h​(p)h​(1)​∑ℱ∈𝔽r,1,p∏v∈ℱ∗θ​(cv),ℙsubscript𝐻𝑟𝑝subscriptℱsubscript𝔽𝑟1𝑝ℙsubscriptℱ𝑟ℱℎ𝑝ℎ1subscriptℱsubscript𝔽𝑟1𝑝subscriptproduct𝑣superscriptℱ𝜃subscript𝑐𝑣{\mathbb{P}}(H_{r}=p)=\sum_{\mathcal{F}\in{\mathbb{F}}_{r,1,p}}{\mathbb{P}}(\mathcal{F}_{(r)}=\mathcal{F})=\frac{h(p)}{h(1)}\,\sum_{\mathcal{F}\in{\mathbb{F}}_{r,1,p}}\prod_{v\in\mathcal{F}^{*}}\theta(c_{v}),

and the desired result follows. ∎

Remark. One can interpret the distribution of Hrsubscript𝐻𝑟H_{r} as the limit when T→∞→𝑇T\to\infty of the distribution at time T−r𝑇𝑟T-r of a Galton-Watson process X𝑋X with offspring distribution θ𝜃\theta started from X0=1subscript𝑋01X_{0}=1 and conditioned on the event {XT=1}subscript𝑋𝑇1\{X_{T}=1\}. This suggests that one may code the combinatorial structure of downward triangles in the whole UIPQ (and not only in a hull of fixed radius) by an infinite tree, which could be viewed as the genealogical tree for a Galton-Watson process with offspring distribution θ𝜃\theta, indexed by nonpositive integer times and conditioned to be equal to 111 at time 00. This interpretation will not be needed in the present work and we omit the details.

Let us now fix integers 0≤u<r0𝑢𝑟0\leq u<r. As explained earlier, the annulus 𝒞​(u,r)𝒞𝑢𝑟\mathcal{C}({u,r}) is the part of the UIPQ that lies between the cycles 𝒞usubscript𝒞𝑢\mathcal{C}_{u} and 𝒞rsubscript𝒞𝑟\mathcal{C}_{r} — recall our convention for 𝒞0subscript𝒞0\mathcal{C}_{0} from Section 2.2 — and 𝒞​(u,r)𝒞𝑢𝑟\mathcal{C}({u,r}) is viewed as a truncated quadrangulation of the cylinder of height r−u𝑟𝑢r-u with boundary sizes (Hu,Hr)subscript𝐻𝑢subscript𝐻𝑟(H_{u},H_{r}). We now specify the root edge of 𝒞​(u,r)𝒞𝑢𝑟\mathcal{C}({u,r}), by declaring that it corresponds to the root of the tree, in the skeleton decomposition of ℋutrsubscriptsuperscriptℋtr𝑢\mathcal{H}^{\mathrm{tr}}_{u}, that carries the root edge of the UIPQ (of course when u=0𝑢0u=0, the root edge is the unique edge of 𝒞0subscript𝒞0\mathcal{C}_{0}).

Let ℱu,r∘subscriptsuperscriptℱ𝑢𝑟\mathcal{F}^{\circ}_{u,r} be the skeleton of 𝒞​(u,r)𝒞𝑢𝑟\mathcal{C}(u,r), which is a random element of ∪p≥1𝔽r−u,p∘subscript𝑝1subscriptsuperscript𝔽𝑟𝑢𝑝\cup_{p\geq 1}{\mathbb{F}}^{\circ}_{r-u,p}. It will be convenient to introduce also the forest ℱu,rsubscriptℱ𝑢𝑟\mathcal{F}_{u,r} (in ∪p≥1𝔽r−u,psubscript𝑝1subscript𝔽𝑟𝑢𝑝\cup_{p\geq 1}{\mathbb{F}}_{r-u,p}) obtained from ℱu,r∘subscriptsuperscriptℱ𝑢𝑟\mathcal{F}^{\circ}_{u,r} by first “forgetting” the distinguished vertex and then applying a uniform random circular permutation to the trees in the sequence.

2.7 The law of the perimeter of hulls

We give a more explicit formula for the distribution of Hrsubscript𝐻𝑟H_{r}.

Proposition 11.

We have, for every r≥1𝑟1r\geq 1 and p≥1𝑝1p\geq 1,

ℙ​(Hr=p)=Kr​κp​(2​πr)pℙsubscript𝐻𝑟𝑝subscript𝐾𝑟subscript𝜅𝑝superscript2subscript𝜋𝑟𝑝{\mathbb{P}}(H_{r}=p)=K_{r}\,\kappa_{p}\,(2\pi_{r})^{p} (12)

where

Proof.

Since

h​(p)h​(1)=1p​2p​κp2​κ1,ℎ𝑝ℎ11𝑝superscript2𝑝subscript𝜅𝑝2subscript𝜅1\frac{h(p)}{h(1)}=\frac{1}{p}\,\frac{2^{p}\kappa_{p}}{2\,\kappa_{1}},

Corollary 9 and (2.7) lead to formula (12). Finally, the bounds (13) and (14) are simple consequences of this explicit formula and the asymptotics (4) for the constants κpsubscript𝜅𝑝\kappa_{p}. To derive (13), we observe that we can find a constant η>0𝜂0\eta>0 such that ℙ​(Hr≥a​r2)ℙsubscript𝐻𝑟𝑎superscript𝑟2{\mathbb{P}}(H_{r}\geq a\,r^{2}) is bounded above by a constant times

r−3​∑p>a​r2p×e−η​p/r2≤Cst.​r−3​∫a​r2/2∞x​e−η​x/r2​dx=Cst.×∫a/2∞y​e−η​y​dy,superscript𝑟3subscript𝑝𝑎superscript𝑟2𝑝superscript𝑒𝜂𝑝superscript𝑟2Cst.superscript𝑟3superscriptsubscript𝑎superscript𝑟22𝑥superscript𝑒𝜂𝑥superscript𝑟2differential-d𝑥Cst.superscriptsubscript𝑎2𝑦superscript𝑒𝜂𝑦differential-d𝑦r^{-3}\sum_{p>ar^{2}}\sqrt{p}\times e^{-\eta p/r^{2}}\leq\hbox{Cst.}\,r^{-3}\int_{ar^{2}/2}^{\infty}\sqrt{x}e^{-\eta x/r^{2}}\mathrm{d}x=\hbox{Cst.}\times\int_{a/2}^{\infty}\sqrt{y}e^{-\eta y}\mathrm{d}y,

and the proof of (14) is even easier just bounding πrsubscript𝜋𝑟\pi_{r} by 111. ∎

2.8 A conditional limit for branching processes

We keep the notation (Yn)n≥0subscriptsubscript𝑌𝑛𝑛0(Y_{n})_{n\geq 0} for a branching process with offspring distribution θ𝜃\theta, which starts at p𝑝p under the probability measure ℙpsubscriptℙ𝑝{\mathbb{P}}_{p}.

Lemma 12.

We have

ℙ1​(Yr≠0)∼r→∞2r2subscriptsimilar-to→𝑟subscriptℙ1subscript𝑌𝑟02superscript𝑟2{\mathbb{P}}_{1}(Y_{r}\not=0)\mathrel{\mathop{\kern 0.0pt\sim}\limits_{r\to\infty}}\frac{2}{r^{2}}

and the distribution of r−2​Yrsuperscript𝑟2subscript𝑌𝑟r^{-2}Y_{r} under ℙ1(⋅∣Yr≠0){\mathbb{P}}_{1}(\cdot\mid Y_{r}\not=0) converges to the distribution with Laplace transform

1−(1+2λ)−2.1superscript12𝜆21-\Big{(}1+\sqrt{\frac{2}{\lambda}}\Big{)}^{-2}.
Proof.

M​nβ−α​exp⁡(A​nβ−2)​exp⁡(−a~0​nα).𝑀superscript𝑛𝛽𝛼𝐴superscript𝑛𝛽2subscript~𝑎0superscript𝑛𝛼M\,n^{\beta-\alpha}\,\exp(A\,n^{\beta-2})\,\exp(-\tilde{a}_{0}n^{\alpha}).

Since β−2<α𝛽2𝛼\beta-2<\alpha, this shows that the left-hand side of (3) goes to 00 faster than any negative power of n𝑛n, uniformly in r≥1𝑟1r\geq 1.

Let us now explain how part (i) of Theorem 1 is derived from Proposition 2.

Proof of Theorem 1 (i). Let R≥1𝑅1R\geq 1 and let ε∈(0,1/2)𝜀012\varepsilon\in(0,1/2). Without loss of generality we can assume that ε​R≥1𝜀𝑅1\varepsilon R\geq 1. Also let n=⌊1/ε⌋𝑛1𝜀n=\lfloor 1/\varepsilon\rfloor so that n​r≤R𝑛𝑟𝑅nr\leq R. Then the cycle γ𝛾\gamma disconnects Bn​r​(𝒫)subscript𝐵𝑛𝑟𝒫B_{nr}({\mathcal{P}}) from infinity, which also implies that it disconnects Bn​r∙​(𝒫)subscriptsuperscript𝐵∙𝑛𝑟𝒫B^{\bullet}_{nr}({\mathcal{P}}) from infinity (in particular, γ𝛾\gamma does not intersect Bn​r∙​(𝒫)subscriptsuperscript𝐵∙𝑛𝑟𝒫B^{\bullet}_{nr}({\mathcal{P}})). Let k≥0𝑘0k\geq 0 be the first integer such that γ𝛾\gamma intersects the annulus 𝒞​((n+k)​r,(n+k+1)​r)𝒞𝑛𝑘𝑟𝑛𝑘1𝑟\mathcal{C}((n+k)r,(n+k+1)r). Then γ𝛾\gamma is contained in 𝒞​((n+k)​r,(n+k+2)​r)𝒞𝑛𝑘𝑟𝑛𝑘2𝑟\mathcal{C}((n+k)r,(n+k+2)r) and does not intersect 𝒞(n+k+2)​rsubscript𝒞𝑛𝑘2𝑟\mathcal{C}_{(n+k+2)r} (otherwise this would contradict the fact that γ𝛾\gamma has length smaller than r𝑟r). These considerations show that the event {L​(R)≤ε​R}𝐿𝑅𝜀𝑅\{L(R)\leq\varepsilon R\} is contained in the union over k≥0𝑘0k\geq 0 of the events where there exists a cycle of length smaller than r𝑟r that is contained in 𝒞​((n+k)​r,(n+k+2)​r)𝒞𝑛𝑘𝑟𝑛𝑘2𝑟\mathcal{C}((n+k)r,(n+k+2)r), does not intersect 𝒞(n+k+2)​rsubscript𝒞𝑛𝑘2𝑟\mathcal{C}_{(n+k+2)r}, and disconnects the root vertex from infinity. Hence, if β∈(1,3)𝛽13\beta\in(1,3) is given, we deduce from Proposition 2 that

ℙ​(L​(R)≤ε​R)≤∑k=0∞Cβ′​(n+k)−β≤C~β​n−β+1=C~β​(⌊1/ε⌋)−β+1.ℙ𝐿𝑅𝜀𝑅superscriptsubscript𝑘0subscriptsuperscript𝐶′𝛽superscript𝑛𝑘𝛽subscript~𝐶𝛽superscript𝑛𝛽1subscript~𝐶𝛽superscript1𝜀𝛽1{\mathbb{P}}(L(R)\leq\varepsilon R)\leq\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}C^{\prime}_{\beta}\,(n+k)^{-\beta}\leq\widetilde{C}_{\beta}\,n^{-\beta+1}=\widetilde{C}_{\beta}(\lfloor 1/\varepsilon\rfloor)^{-\beta+1}.

The result of Theorem 1 (i) follows. □□\square

4 Upper bound on the size of the separating cycle

In this section, we prove Theorem 1 (ii). We recall the notation ℱu,wsubscriptℱ𝑢𝑤\mathcal{F}_{u,w} introduced before Corollary 10, for integers 0≤u<w0𝑢𝑤0\leq u<w. We write Nu,wsubscript𝑁𝑢𝑤N_{u,w} for the number of trees of ℱu,wsubscriptℱ𝑢𝑤\mathcal{F}_{u,w} that have maximal height w−u𝑤𝑢w-u. As explained in Section 2.4, for every integer R≥3𝑅3R\geq 3, one can find a cycle of the UIPT that disconnects the ball BR−2​(𝒫)subscript𝐵𝑅2𝒫B_{R-2}({\mathcal{P}}) from infinity and whose length is bounded above by 2​R​NR,2​R2𝑅subscript𝑁𝑅2𝑅2R\,N_{R,2R}. In order to get bounds on NR,2​Rsubscript𝑁𝑅2𝑅N_{R,2R}, we determine more generally the distribution of Nu,wsubscript𝑁𝑢𝑤N_{u,w} for any 1≤u<w1𝑢𝑤1\leq u<w.

Proposition 14.

The generating function of Nu,wsubscript𝑁𝑢𝑤N_{u,w} is given by

5 Isoperimetric inequalities

In this section, we prove Theorem 3 and Proposition 4. We start with the proof of Proposition 4, which is easier.

Proof of Proposition 4. We first observe that we can assume that n𝑛n is larger than some fixed integer, by then adjusting the constant cεsubscript𝑐𝜀c_{\varepsilon} if necessary. In agreement with the notation of the introduction, write |Br∙​(𝒫)|subscriptsuperscript𝐵∙𝑟𝒫|B^{\bullet}_{r}({\mathcal{P}})| for the number of faces of the UIPQ contained in the standard hull Br∙​(𝒫)subscriptsuperscript𝐵∙𝑟𝒫B^{\bullet}_{r}({\mathcal{P}}).

It follows that we can fix an integer M>0𝑀0M>0 such that, for every r≥1𝑟1r\geq 1,

ℙ​(|Br∙​(𝒫)|<M​r4)≥1−ε2.ℙsubscriptsuperscript𝐵∙𝑟𝒫𝑀superscript𝑟41𝜀2{\mathbb{P}}(|B^{\bullet}_{r}({\mathcal{P}})|<M\,r^{4})\geq 1-\frac{\varepsilon}{2}. (30)

By Theorem 1, we can fix N≥1𝑁1N\geq 1 large enough so that ℙ​(Er,N)>1−ε/2ℙsubscript𝐸𝑟𝑁1𝜀2{\mathbb{P}}(E_{r,N})>1-\varepsilon/2 for every r≥1𝑟1r\geq 1.

We fix c>0𝑐0c>0 such that M​(N+1)4​c4<1𝑀superscript𝑁14superscript𝑐41M(N+1)^{4}c^{4}<1. Then, let n≥1𝑛1n\geq 1 large enough so that c​n1/4≥1𝑐superscript𝑛141cn^{1/4}\geq 1 and M​((N+1)​⌈c​n1/4⌉)4<n𝑀superscript𝑁1𝑐superscript𝑛144𝑛M((N+1)\lceil cn^{1/4}\rceil)^{4}<n. We argue on the event

    If dgr​(Δ,∂A)>N​⌈c​n1/4⌉+1subscriptdgrΔ𝐴𝑁𝑐superscript𝑛141\mathrm{d}_{\mathrm{gr}}(\Delta,\partial A)>N\lceil cn^{1/4}\rceil+1, we note that the ball BN​⌈c​n1/4⌉​(𝒫)subscript𝐵𝑁𝑐superscript𝑛14𝒫B_{N\lceil cn^{1/4}\rceil}({\mathcal{P}}) is separated from infinity by the cycle ∂A𝐴\partial A, which implies that |∂A|≥c​n1/4𝐴𝑐superscript𝑛14|\partial A|\geq c\,n^{1/4} by the very definition of the event EN​⌈c​n1/4⌉,Nsubscript𝐸𝑁𝑐superscript𝑛14𝑁E_{N\lceil cn^{1/4}\rceil,N}.

  • ∙∙\bullet

    If dgr​(Δ,∂A)≤N​⌈c​n1/4⌉+1subscriptdgrΔ𝐴𝑁𝑐superscript𝑛141\mathrm{d}_{\mathrm{gr}}(\Delta,\partial A)\leq N\lceil cn^{1/4}\rceil+1, then we argue by contradiction assuming that |∂A|<c​n1/4𝐴𝑐superscript𝑛14|\partial A|<c\,n^{1/4} and in particular the diameter of ∂A𝐴\partial A is bounded above by ⌈c​n1/4⌉−1𝑐superscript𝑛141\lceil c\,n^{1/4}\rceil-1. To simplify notation, we set rn=(N+1)​⌈c​n1/4⌉subscript𝑟𝑛𝑁1𝑐superscript𝑛14r_{n}=(N+1)\lceil cn^{1/4}\rceil. The property dgr​(Δ,∂A)≤N​⌈c​n1/4⌉+1subscriptdgrΔ𝐴𝑁𝑐superscript𝑛141\mathrm{d}_{\mathrm{gr}}(\Delta,\partial A)\leq N\lceil cn^{1/4}\rceil+1 ensures that any vertex of ∂A𝐴\partial A is at distance at most rnsubscript𝑟𝑛r_{n} from ΔΔ\Delta, and therefore any edge of ∂A𝐴\partial A is incident to a vertex at distance at most rn−1subscript𝑟𝑛1r_{n}-1 from ΔΔ\Delta. It follows that any face incident to an edge of ∂A𝐴\partial A is contained in the hull Brn∙​(𝒫)subscriptsuperscript𝐵∙subscript𝑟𝑛𝒫B^{\bullet}_{r_{n}}({\mathcal{P}}). Consequently, the whole boundary ∂A𝐴\partial A is contained in Brn∙​(𝒫)subscriptsuperscript𝐵∙subscript𝑟𝑛𝒫B^{\bullet}_{r_{n}}({\mathcal{P}}), and so is the set A𝐴A. In particular, |A|≤|Brn∙​(𝒫)|<n𝐴subscriptsuperscript𝐵∙subscript𝑟𝑛𝒫𝑛|A|\leq|B^{\bullet}_{r_{n}}({\mathcal{P}})|<n, which is a contradiction with our assumption |A|≥n𝐴𝑛|A|\geq n.

This completes the proof of Proposition 4. □□\square

Before we proceed to the proof of Theorem 3, we state a proposition which is a key ingredient of this proof.

Proposition 15.

There exists a constant M0subscript𝑀0M_{0} such that, for every r≥1𝑟1r\geq 1,

𝔼​[|Br∙​(𝒫)|]≤M0​r4.𝔼delimited-[]subscriptsuperscript𝐵∙𝑟𝒫subscript𝑀0superscript𝑟4{\mathbb{E}}[|B^{\bullet}_{r}({\mathcal{P}})|]\leq M_{0}\,r^{4}.

We postpone the proof of Proposition 15 to the end of the section.

Proof of Theorem 3. Thanks to Proposition 15 and Markov’s inequality, we have for every r≥1𝑟1r\geq 1, for every a>0𝑎0a>0,

ℙ​(|Br∙​(𝒫)|≥a)≤M0​r4a.ℙsubscriptsuperscript𝐵∙𝑟𝒫𝑎subscript𝑀0superscript𝑟4𝑎{\mathbb{P}}(|B^{\bullet}_{r}({\mathcal{P}})|\geq a)\leq\frac{M_{0}r^{4}}{a}. (31)

cp=p−34−δsubscript𝑐𝑝superscript𝑝34𝛿c_{p}=p^{-\frac{3}{4}-\delta}

and

∑p=1∞ℙ​(ENp​⌈cp​2p/4⌉,Npc)<∞.superscriptsubscript𝑝1ℙsuperscriptsubscript𝐸subscript𝑁𝑝subscript𝑐𝑝superscript2𝑝4subscript𝑁𝑝𝑐\sum_{p=1}^{\infty}{\mathbb{P}}(E_{N_{p}\lceil c_{p}2^{p/4}\rceil,N_{p}}^{c})<\infty.

∑p=1∞ℙ​(|B(Np+1)​⌈cp​2p/4⌉∙​(𝒫)|≥2p)<∞.superscriptsubscript𝑝1ℙsubscriptsuperscript𝐵∙subscript𝑁𝑝1subscript𝑐𝑝superscript2𝑝4𝒫superscript2𝑝\sum_{p=1}^{\infty}{\mathbb{P}}(|B^{\bullet}_{(N_{p}+1)\lceil c_{p}2^{p/4}\rceil}({\mathcal{P}})|\geq 2^{p})<\infty.

We still have to prove Proposition 15. We note that the continuous analog of the UIPQ, or of the UIPT, is the Brownian plane introduced in [5]. For every r>0𝑟0r>0 the definition of the hull of radius r𝑟r makes sense in the Brownian plane and the explicit distribution of the volume of the hull was computed in [6], showing in particular that the expected volume is finite and (by scaling invariance) equal to a constant times r4superscript𝑟4r^{4}. On the other hand, in the case of the UIPT, Ménard [19] was recently able to compute the exact distribution of the volume of hulls. Such an exact expression is not yet available in the case of the UIPQ, and so we use a different method based on the skeleton decomposition.

Before we proceed to the proof of Proposition 15, we state a lemma concerning truncated quadrangulations with a Boltzmann distribution. Let p≥1𝑝1p\geq 1. We say that a random truncated quadrangulation 𝐌𝐌\mathbf{M} with boundary size p≥1𝑝1p\geq 1 is Boltzmann distributed if, for every integer n≥1𝑛1n\geq 1, for every ℳ∈ℚn,ptrℳsubscriptsuperscriptℚtr𝑛𝑝\mathcal{M}\in{\mathbb{Q}}^{\mathrm{tr}}_{n,p}, ℙ​(𝐌=ℳ)=Z​(p)−1​ 12−nℙ𝐌ℳ𝑍superscript𝑝1superscript12𝑛{\mathbb{P}}(\mathbf{M}=\mathcal{M})=Z(p)^{-1}\,12^{-n}.

Lemma 16.

There exists a constant L0>0subscript𝐿00L_{0}>0 such that, for every p≥1𝑝1p\geq 1, if 𝐌psubscript𝐌𝑝\mathbf{M}_{p} is a Boltzmann distributed truncated quadrangulation with boundary size p𝑝p,

Proof of Proposition 15. 𝔼​[(1+ξ1)2​exp⁡(−a12​r2​ξ1)]≤L4​r𝔼delimited-[]superscript1subscript𝜉12subscript𝑎12superscript𝑟2subscript𝜉1subscript𝐿4𝑟{\mathbb{E}}\Big{[}(1+\xi_{1})^{2}\,\exp(-\frac{a_{1}}{2r^{2}}\xi_{1})\Big{]}\leq L_{4}r

for some constant L4subscript𝐿4L_{4}. Moreover, we can also find a constant a2>0subscript𝑎20a_{2}>0 such that

with some other constant L5subscript𝐿5L_{5}.

Appendix. Proof of Lemma 13

We first note that 𝒫k,K​(r)subscript𝒫𝑘𝐾𝑟{\mathcal{P}}_{k,K}(r) is trivially empty if k>2​K/(c​r2)𝑘2𝐾𝑐superscript𝑟2k>2K/(cr^{2}). So we may assume that k≥k0𝑘subscript𝑘0k\geq k_{0} where k0subscript𝑘0k_{0} can be taken large (but fixed).

≤M×⌊Kn​c​r2⌋×ℙ​(min0≤ℓ≤n​c​r2⁡S​(ℓ)≥−10​r)Nkabsent𝑀𝐾𝑛𝑐superscript𝑟2ℙsuperscriptsubscript0ℓ𝑛𝑐superscript𝑟2𝑆ℓ10𝑟subscript𝑁𝑘\displaystyle\leq M\times\lfloor\frac{K}{ncr^{2}}\rfloor\times{\mathbb{P}}\Big{(}\min_{0\leq\ell\leq ncr^{2}}S(\ell)\geq-10r\Big{)}^{N_{k}}
≤M×⌊Kn​c​r2⌋×αNkabsent𝑀𝐾𝑛𝑐superscript𝑟2superscript𝛼subscript𝑁𝑘\displaystyle\leq M\times\lfloor\frac{K}{ncr^{2}}\rfloor\times\alpha^{N_{k}}

using the strong Markov property of S𝑆S in the second line, and our choice of n𝑛n in the last one. We conclude that

ℙ​(𝒫k,K∗∗​(r))≤ℙ​(ℰk,K​(r))≤M×⌊Kn​c​r2⌋×αNkℙsubscriptsuperscript𝒫absent𝑘𝐾𝑟ℙsubscriptℰ𝑘𝐾𝑟𝑀𝐾𝑛𝑐superscript𝑟2superscript𝛼subscript𝑁𝑘{\mathbb{P}}({\mathcal{P}}^{**}_{k,K}(r))\leq{\mathbb{P}}(\mathcal{E}_{k,K}(r))\leq M\times\lfloor\frac{K}{ncr^{2}}\rfloor\times\alpha^{N_{k}}

and since we have

ℙ​(𝒫k,K​(r))≤(c​k​r24​K)−1×2​ℙ​(𝒫k,K∗∗​(r))ℙsubscript𝒫𝑘𝐾𝑟superscript𝑐𝑘superscript𝑟24𝐾12ℙsubscriptsuperscript𝒫absent𝑘𝐾𝑟{\mathbb{P}}({\mathcal{P}}_{k,K}(r))\leq\Big{(}\frac{ckr^{2}}{4K}\Big{)}^{-1}\times 2\,{\mathbb{P}}({\mathcal{P}}^{**}_{k,K}(r))

we get the bound of the lemma.
